i Installed ubuntu on an external hard drive but it automatically put grub in my internal hard drives boot sector, so now i can't boot my computer without the external plugged in... is there a way to move grub to the external?
when the system is booted, you can install grub with 'sudo grub-install install_device', where install_device is something like /dev/sda
once that's done, you need to fix grub on the internal disk so it doesn't rely on the external one any more. Or replace it with another bootloader.
of course it can. But then you won't have a bootloader. And a system that won't boot. Hint: that's not what you want ;)
yes. It was using the Windows bootloader, which is now overwritten by grub.
about 99.8% of people want to boot with grub, that's why it doesn't ask.
I suggest you find a way to add a boot option for Linux in NTLDR (the Windows bootloader). There are howtos for that on the net.
you will have to use a Windows install CD to "repair" NTLDR
if that's what you prefer, you can install grub for NT.
I don't know much about it, I think it's slightly experimental. Again, search the web if that is the way you want to go
NT is the technology base for the current Windows products
what horrors? You're being helped by friendly guys ;)
the other thing you can do is create a micro boot partition on the internal disk just for the stuff that grub needs
it doesn't mean you would lose anything
and what do you have a backup for, anyway
